facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 263 of 1964 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 263 of 1964.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated July 2, 1964 of Allahabad High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 356 of 1964 and Ref. No. 15 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 2, 1964 of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 356 of 1964 and Ref. No. 15 of 1964.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court affirmed conviction for offences under ss. 302, 307 and 324 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant has appealed from the judgment of the High Court at Allahabad affirming his conviction for offences under ss. 302, 307 and 324, Indian Penal Code

facts.text: High Court confirmed death sentence for offence under s. 302 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: and confirming the sentence of death passed upon him in respect of the offence under s. 302 and also affirming the sentences passed in respect of the other two offences.

facts.text: Appellant quarrelled with Mangali PW 1 over grazing of cattle in Mangali's field damaging crops.

anchor.surface_text: The facts as found by the High Court are these The appellant had quarrelled with Mangali, PW 1, as Mangali reprimanded him over the grazing of his cattle in Mangalis field and damaging his crops.

facts.text: Appellant threatened Mangali that he would exterminate the latter's family.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant threatened Mangali that he would exterminate the latters family.

facts.text: On February 25, 1957 at about 3:00 p.m., children were playing near hut of Hiralal PW 3.

anchor.surface_text: On February 25, 1957 at about 3-00 p.m. Babu Ram son of Mangali, aged about 7 or 8 years, Ram Ratia, aged about 2 years, daughter of Mangalis brother and Punna, son of Baijnath, brother of Mangali and Dulli,

facts.text: Babu Ram, son of Mangali, aged about 7 or 8 years, was playing.

anchor.surface_text: Babu Ram son of Mangali, aged about 7 or 8 years,

facts.text: Ram Ratia, aged about 2 years, daughter of Mangali's brother, was playing.

anchor.surface_text: Ram Ratia, aged about 2 years, daughter of Mangalis brother

facts.text: Punna, son of Baijnath brother of Mangali, was playing.

anchor.surface_text: Punna, son of Baijnath, brother of Mangali

facts.text: Dulli, daughter of Ladda Kewat, aged about 10 or 11 years, was playing.

anchor.surface_text: Dulli, daughter of one Ladda Kewat, aged about 10 or 11 years and some other children were playing

facts.text: Appellant came armed with a sickle and rushed at the children.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant came there armed with a sickle and rushed at the children.

facts.text: Appellant first struck a blow on Babu Ram, who fled away and started crying.

anchor.surface_text: He first struck a blow on Babu Ram, who fled away and started crying.

facts.text: Mangali's one year old daughter Lachhminia was there; appellant ripped open her chest with sickle, she died almost immediately.

anchor.surface_text: Mangalis one year old daughter Lachhminia was also there at that time and the appellant ripped open that childs chest with the sickle as a result of which she died almost immediately.

facts.text: Appellant struck blows on Ram Ratia and Punna.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then struck blows on Ram Ratia and also on Punna.

facts.text: Hiralal, brother of appellant PW 3, sleeping in hut, awakened by cries, rushed out to save children; appellant struck him.

anchor.surface_text: Hiralal, the brother of the appellant who was sleeping in his hut was awakened by the cries of children and rushed out to save them. Thereupon the appellant struck a blow on Hiralal as well.

facts.text: Villagers rushed to spot on hearing cries; appellant escaped by running to river Ganges 75 paces away, jumped in, swam to other shore, absconded.

anchor.surface_text: Hearing the cries of children a number of villagers rushed to the spot but the appellant escaped from their clutches by running towards the river Ganges which is at a distance of about 75 paces from the place of the incident, jumped into the water and swam to the other shore and absconded.

facts.text: Proceedings under ss. 87 and 88 CrPC started against appellant on October 11, 1957; proceeded as absconder.

anchor.surface_text: On October 11, 1957 proceedings under ss. 87 and 88 of the Code of Criminal Procedure were started against him and he was eventually proceeded against as an absconder.

facts.text: Appellant arrested on February 1, 1963 and sent for trial.

anchor.surface_text: It was only on February 1, 1963 that he was arrested and thereafter sent up for trial.

facts.text: At trial, appellant convicted and sentenced as stated.

anchor.surface_text: At that trial he was convicted and sentenced, as already stated.

facts.text: Appellant did not plead defence of insanity in examination under s. 342 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: even though in his examination under s. 342 of the Code of Criminal Procedure the appellant did not plead the defence of insanity.

facts.text: Counsel for appellant argued lack of mens rea due to insanity.

anchor.surface_text: The only point urged by Mr. Varma who appears for the appellant is that the appellant was a person of unsound mind and that he was not in a position to know or realise the nature of the acts

facts.text: Dulli PW 6 stated appellant was insane when he attacked.

anchor.surface_text: and also to the specific statement of the former to the effect that the appellant was insane when he attacked the children.

facts.text: Hiralal PW 3 and Dulli referred to appellant as pagalwa.

anchor.surface_text: he then refers to the statement of Dulli, P.W. 6, and that of Hiralal P.W. 3 in which the appellant is referred to as pagalwa

facts.text: Court found appellant sane; rejected insanity defence.

anchor.surface_text: We entirely agree with these observations of the learned Sessions Judge and also with the conclusion arrived at by him that the case of the appellant does not fall under the exception created by s. 84 of the Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Appellant conducted cultivation up to time of occurrence.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, there is evidence that up to the time of occurrence he has been doing his cultivation.

facts.text: Few months before occurrence, appellant quarrelled with Mangali and Bhaiya Lal, threatened to make their family extinct.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, few months before the occurrence the accused admittedly picked up quarrel with Mangali and Bhaiya Lal and had given threatening to make their family indistinct.

facts.text: Appellant first attacked children of Mangali and Bhaiya Lal family, not others.

anchor.surface_text: But first of all he gave a sickle blow only to Babu Ram and other children of the family of Mangali and Bhaiya Lal and not to any other children.

facts.text: Appellant beat Hiralal only when he tried to stop the attack.

anchor.surface_text: He beat Hira Lal only when he tried to stop the act of beating of the children of Mangali and Bhaiya Lals family with whom he had picked up quarrel previously.

facts.text: Appellant ran away fearing, jumped into Ganges.

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, a sense of fear prevailed in him and that is why he acted like a sane man by running and then escaping by jumping into the Ganges river.

anchor.surface_text: Section 84 of the Penal Code, one of the provisions in Ch. IV of the Penal Code, which deals with General Exceptions provides as follows Act of a person of unsound mind. Nothing is an offence which is done by a person who, at the time of doing it, by reason of unsoundness of mind, is incapable of knowing the nature of the act, or that he is doing what is either wrong or contrary to law .

concepts.interpretation: Exception not applicable as accused failed to prove unsoundness of mind; acted with deliberation, motive, and sanity inferred from conduct

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 105 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 the burden of proving the existence of circumstances bringing the case within any of the exceptions specified in the Penal Code lies upon the accused person. It further provides that in such a case the Court shall presume the absence of such circumstances.

issues.text: Whether the appellant was a person of unsound mind at the time of committing the offence and incapable of knowing the nature of the act or that it was wrong or contrary to law under Section 84 IPC

anchor.surface_text: The only point urged by Mr. Varma who appears for the appellant is that the appellant was a person of unsound mind and that he was not in a position to know or realise the nature of the acts which he was committing.

issues.text: Whether the prosecution must prove the sanity of the accused or establish absence of circumstances bringing the case under exceptions like Section 84 IPC, or whether the burden lies on the accused under Section 105 of the Evidence Act

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 105 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 the burden of proving the existence of circumstances bringing the case within any of the exceptions specified in the Penal Code lies upon the accused person. It further provides that in such a case the Court shall presume the absence of such circumstances.

issues.text: Whether mens rea was proved by the prosecution beyond reasonable doubt for the offences under Sections 302, 307 and 324 IPC despite the insanity plea

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel argued that mens rea being an essential ingredient of all the offences with which the appellant was charged his conviction with respect to any of them cannot be sustained for the simple reason that no intention to cause death or to cause any injury whether resulting in death or not could possibly be attributed to a person who, when he committed the acts, was insane.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Varma further contends that there is evidence on record from which it can be inferred that the appellant was a person of unsound mind. In the first place, he points out, that no man in his senses will go on attacking children indiscriminately and go to the length of ripping open the chest of one year old child.

arguments.claim: Prosecution must prove mens rea beyond reasonable doubt from circumstances; intention inferred from using deadly weapon on body parts likely to cause death

anchor.surface_text: There is no doubt that the burden of proving an offence is always on the prosecution... Thus if a person deliberately strikes another with a deadly weapon, which according to the common experience of mankind is likely to cause an injury and sometimes even a fatal injury depending upon the quality of the weapon and the part of the body on which it is struck, it would be reasonable to infer that what the accused did was accompanied by the intention to cause a kind of injury which in fact resulted from the act.

anchor.surface_text: Everyone is presumed to know the natural consequences of his act. Similarly everyone is also presumed to know the law. These are not facts which the prosecution has to establish. It is for this reason that s. 105 of the Evidence Act places upon the accused person the burden of proving the exception upon which he relies.

holdings.text: Under s. 105 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 the burden of proving the existence of circumstances bringing the case within any of the exceptions specified in the Penal Code lies upon the accused person. It further provides that in such a case the Court shall presume the absence of such circumstances.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 105 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 the burden of proving the existence of circumstances bringing the case within any of the exceptions specified in the Penal Code lies upon the accused person. It further provides that in such a case the Court shall presume the absence of such circumstances.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory text of s.105 Evidence Act places burden on accused for general exceptions like insanity; court presumes absence unless proved.

holdings.text: There is no doubt that the burden of proving an offence is always on the prosecution and that it never shifts. It would, therefore, be correct to say that intention when it is an essential ingredient of an offence, has also to be established by the prosecution. But the state of mind of a person can ordinarily only be inferred from circumstances.

anchor.surface_text: There is no doubt that the burden of proving an offence is always on the prosecution and that it never shifts. It would, therefore, be correct to say that intention when it is an essential ingredient of an offence, has also to be established by the prosecution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Mens rea inferred from factual circumstances like deliberate use of deadly weapon on vital parts; prosecution discharges burden thereby.

holdings.text: Undoubtedly it is for the prosecution to prove beyond reasonable doubt that the accused had committed the offence with the requisite mens rea. Once that is done a presumption that the accused was sane when he committed the offence would arise. This presumption is rebuttable and he can rebut it either by leading evidence or by relying upon the prosecution evidence itself.

anchor.surface_text: This passage does not say anything different from what we have said earlier. Undoubtedly it is for the prosecution to prove beyond reasonable doubt that the accused had committed the offence with the requisite mens rea. Once that is done a presumption that the accused was sane when he committed the offence would arise.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clarifying Dahyabhai precedent: prosecution proves act and mens rea first, triggering rebuttable presumption of sanity under s.105 Evidence Act; accused bears burden thereafter or raises doubt.

holdings.text: We entirely agree with these observations of the learned Sessions Judge and also with the conclusion arrived at by him that the case of the appellant does not fall under the exception created by s. 84 of the Indian Penal Code.

anchor.surface_text: We entirely agree with these observations of the learned Sessions Judge and also with the conclusion arrived at by him that the case of the appellant does not fall under the exception created by s. 84 of the Indian Penal Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accused failed to rebut presumption of sanity; prior threats and cultivation, selective targeting of rival family children, attacking intervener only, flight showing fear indicate deliberation, motive, knowledge; unreliable interested witnesses; brutality not proof of insanity.

holdings.text: the indiscriminate manner in which the appellant attacked three innocent children and particularly his act of ripping open the chest of Lachhminia only shows the brutality of the assailant and cannot reasonably be regarded as a circumstance from which it could be inferred that he was of unsound mind.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Varma further contends that there is evidence on record from which it can be inferred that the appellant was a person of unsound mind. In the first place, he points out, that no man in his senses will go on attacking children indiscriminately and go to the length of ripping open the chest of one year old child.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Brutality of attack on children does not equate to unsoundness of mind; consistent with motive from prior quarrel.

precedents.citation: Dahyabhai Chhaganbhai Thakkar v. State of Gujarat 1

anchor.surface_text: Dahyabhai Chhaganbhai Thakkar v. State of Gujarat 1

precedents.case_name: Dahyabhai Chhaganbhai Thakkar v. State of Gujarat
precedents.cited_proposition: Prosecution must prove beyond reasonable doubt that accused committed offence with requisite mens rea; rebuttable presumption of sanity; accused bears burden no higher than civil standard to prove insanity; evidence raising reasonable doubt as to mens rea entitles acquittal
precedents.cited_holding: The doctrine of burden of proof in the context of the plea of insanity may be stated in the following propositions: 1. The prosecution must prove beyond reasonable doubt that the accused had committed the offence with the requisite mens rea... 3. Even if the accused was not able to establish conclusively that he was insane... the court would be entitled to acquit...

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 105 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 the burden of proving the existence of circumstances bringing the case within any of the exceptions specified in the Penal Code lies upon the accused person. It further provides that in such a case the Court shall presume the absence of such circumstances.

Under s. 105 of the Indian Evidence Act, 1872 the burden of proving the existence of circumstances bringing the case within any of the exceptions specified in the Penal Code lies upon the accused person. It further provides that in such a case the Court shall presume the absence of such circumstances.

anchor.surface_text: There is no doubt that the burden of proving an offence is always on the prosecution and that it never shifts. It would, therefore, be correct to say that intention when it is an essential ingredient of an offence, has also to be established by the prosecution.
